August 28, 1953
Mr. C. Scott Fletcher, President
Fund for Adult Education
914 East Green Street
Pasadena 1, California
Dear Mr. Fletcher:
The National Congress of Parents and Teachers, an organization of
almost eight million men and women interested in the welfare of all
children, is much concerned with the impact of television. Use of
television in the school is a problem which is being presented to
us more and more often.
Often we are asked if we approve of the use of television m the
classrooms; if we approve of local P.T.A.'s purchasing TV equipment.
Always our reply has been to the effect that while we recognize the
educational value of television, we feel it necessary that teachers
understand and favor its use; that they have the needed training to
use it adequately in the classroom. Nothing can destroy a positive attiÂ¬
tude on the part of the public more quickly than inefficient or
wasteful use of the medium. Unless teachers are given such preparation,
they cannot be criti ised for their lack of acceptance or competence
in use of TV.
<
Dr. Belmont Farley, the representative of the National Education
Association on the Joint Committee on Educational Television, has
Shown me the NEA application for funds to begin a service to teachers
and administrators in educational television. This proposed project
seems to be timely and needed. It will supplement the efforts of
organizations already active in the field. Through membership of the
NEA and the affiliated Stqte branches it will be available m all
sections of our country, to teachers from every area of activity.
We trust that you will consider this project favorably and assist
iq initiating such service to teachers and thereby indirectly bene-
fitting all children.
Sincerely yours,
Mrs. Newton-P. Leonard, President
National Congress of Parents and Teachers
